results.title: Film firsts. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: Paul Killiam, Saul J. Turell and Gregstan Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
This film spotlights the remarkable achievements of a quartet of great film pioneers, Edwin S.Porter, Georges Melies, Thomas H.Ince, and D.W.Griffith, who in a few years prior to 1914 brought imagination, drama, technical innovations and photographic trickery to the screen. Illustrated by excerpts from the films.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Killiam, Saul J. Turell and Gregstan Enterprises

results.title: Film firsts. Pt. 1
results.creator_credit: Paul Killiam, Saul J. Turell and Gregstan Enterprises
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
Traces the techniques and situations used by film makers during the early years of experimentation with the film medium. In its first two decades the industry tried almost all of the techniques and situations which were to be developed or reintroduced later. Specific names, dates, and excerpts from early films illustrate the work of innovators in techniques, equipment, stories, themes, roles and industry operation. Developments include the first use of synchronized sound; tracking with movie cameras; animation; models; props, and camera trickery for special effects, and underwater photography.

results.title: Film exercise
results.creator_credit: Rodney Charters and University of Auckland. School of Fine Arts
results.brief_description: This first film by a young New Zealand art student uses the motorcycle as a sex symbol in the lives of the “beat” generation…a girl’s infatuation with a motorcycle and its rider. This film was made as a design project at the School of Fine Arts, University of Auckland, and makes interesting use of various film techniques.

results.title: Film editing: interpretation and evaluation
results.brief_description: Contrasts the work of three Hollywood editors. Shows that the manner in which the film is sequenced, determines the dramatic effect. Firstly we see the film exactly as shot for a dramatic sequence, showing all scenes from various angles. Following these are three editing interpretations of the sequence by different editors. Demonstrates how, in assembling the shots, by omitting and shortening others and by different juxtaposition, the editor may control the dramatic construction. Looks at how a scene from the television series “Gunsmoke” is interpreted by different editing.

results.title: Film and you
results.creator_credit: Donald Peters, Jean Palardy, Donald Fraser and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film describes how film councils are organised, and what they can do for the community. Different people like different things - for instance, Grandpa, who goes to sleep during a sequence on kitchen planning, wakes joyfully at the sound of a square dance. But all groups agree that they want films on their programs, if they can get them, and that is where the film council comes in. Animation shows how a council is set up, and how a number of organisations in an area can collaborate in buying a projector. We see projectionist training, and the public library becoming a distribution centre for films as well as books. Finally, we see film in action, as a variety of successful community projects are carried out, each directly the result of film showings.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald Peters, Jean Palardy, Donald Fraser and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Film and reality
results.creator_credit: Alberto Cavalcanti, Ernest Lindgren and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: A compilation documentary which follows the history of Realist film from the earliest days until World War II. The film is presented in five sections - early Realist film and its divorce from film drama; foundations of the Realist film; romantic documentary on “Far-Off Lands”; the Realistic Documentary of “Life at home”; Realism and the Story Film - the Feature Film. Some of the films on display are: Nanook of the North, Rien que les heures, The General Line, Drifters etc.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alberto Cavalcanti, Ernest Lindgren and British Film Institute

results.title: The Figurehead
results.creator_credit: John Halas, Joy Batchelor and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: The animated story of a carved saint who is accidentally changed into a sailor and sold as a figurehead on a sailing ship. A beautiful mermaid falls in love with him, but even when the ship is destroyed and he joins her under the sea, he does not respond because he feels that, beneath his paint, he remains a saint. Based on the poem by Crosbie Garstin.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Halas, Joy Batchelor and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films

results.title: Figure skating
results.creator_credit: Ernest Reid, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An invitation to experience the thrill of spinning, jumping, skimming, and dancing on winged feet. The film shows how Canada’s champions do it. Maria and Otto Jelinek, Don Jackson, Wendy Griner and Don McPherson appear briefly in dazzling exhibition, but the main object of the film is to show that figure skating is for everyone - children, young people, and adults.

results.title: Fighting the cattle tick
results.brief_description: Shows how new knowledge of the cattle tick has led to more efficient methods of control by pasture spelling and strategic dipping.
results.description: Shows how new knowledge of the cattle tick has led to more efficient methods of control by pasture spelling and strategic dipping.
